overall_score_comment: Like a participation trophy for vague optimism—everybody gets one!
the_roast:
Let's address the elephant on the midnight train: 'South Detroit' doesn't exist, Steve Perry. You're literally singing about a fictional place like it's the hometown on someone's dating profile. The whole song reads like someone's creative writing assignment where the prompt was 'be as nonspecific as humanly possible.' Small town girl meets city boy, both somehow taking the SAME midnight train going 'anywhere'—that's not romantic, that's just poor travel planning and a concerning lack of destination awareness.

The imagery here is chef's kiss vague: 'A singer in a smokey room'—what singer? Singing what? And 'the smell of wine and cheap perfume' sounds less like romance and more like someone's describing a Spirit Airlines flight at 2 AM. Then we get the profound observation that 'some will win, some will lose'—wow, thanks Journey, that's really narrowed it down. What's next, 'some people are tall, some are short'? The depth is truly staggering.

But the real MVP here is 'streetlights, people'—a two-word phrase so vague it could describe literally any city at any time. It's like playing lyrical Mad Libs but forgetting to fill in the actual details. And after all this scenic tour of Vagueville, the big inspirational payoff is just 'don't stop believin''—believing in WHAT, exactly? The midnight train schedule? The existence of South Detroit? The hope that this song will eventually tell us what's actually happening?

cliche_counter.quip: Because apparently they couldn't afford the rights to 'uptown girl'
That's not adventurous, that's just having no return ticket
The only gamble here is whether this metaphor will ever pay off

cliche_counter.cliche: Some will win, some will lose
cliche_counter.quip: Yes, and some will write incredibly obvious lyrics
While others were apparently born to sing about street infrastructure

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Born and raised in South Detroit
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory map-reading classes and a public apology to Michigan
Must complete all thoughts before leaving the recording studio

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: The movie never ends, it goes on and on and on and on
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Describing my feelings about this repetitive chorus

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Livin' just to find emotion, hidin' somewhere in the night
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Community service explaining what this actually means

hidden_meanings: This is clearly an allegory about two people with terrible navigation skills who meet at a train station and bond over their shared inability to pick a destination. The 'streetlights' represent society's harsh fluorescent judgment, while 'people' symbolizes... other people. Groundbreaking stuff.
final_verdict: It's the musical equivalent of a fortune cookie—sounds inspirational until you realize it could apply to literally anyone, anywhere, doing anything. But hey, it's been stuck in our heads for four decades, so joke's on us.
title: Don't Stop Believin'
